Introduction to Mechanics on Manifolds Preface
Introduction to Mechanics on Manifolds Astrick 2023-01-16 Preface

1 Partition of Unity Definition 1.1 (Support) The support of a function \(f: X → ℝ\) of a topological space \(X\) is the closure of the set \[ \{x ∈ X: f(x) ≠ 0\} \] relative to \(X\). Remark. Always remember the support of a function is a closure taken relative to its domain of definition. Definition 1.2 (Locally finite) A collection of subsets \(\mathcal A\) of a topological space \(X\) is said to be locally finite in \(X\) if all \(x ∈ X\) has a neighborhood intersecting only finite many sets in \(\mathcal A\). Definition 1.3 (Partition of unity) A collection of smooth functions \(\mathcal R = \{ρ: U → I = [0, 1]\}\) is said to be a smooth partition of unity on open set \(U ⊂ ℝ^n\) if The supports \[\{\mathop{\mathrm{supp}}ρ: ρ ∈ \mathcal R\}\] is locally finite in \(X\); For all \(x ∈ U\), \[\sum_{ρ ∈ \mathcal R} ρ(x) = 1,\] where the notation is defined as \[\sum_{ρ ∈ \mathcal R}ρ(x) := \sum_{ρ∈\mathcal R, ρ(x) ≠ 0}ρ(x)\] which is a finite sum by above local finiteness. Theorem 1.1 There exists a partition of unity for all open sets \(U \in \mathbb R^n\).

2 Half Spaces Definition 2.1 (Half spaces) The half space of dimension \(n\) is given as \[ ℍ^n := \{x ∈ ℝ^n: π^n(x) ≥ 0\} \] where \(π^n(x^1, …, x^n) = x^n\) is the \(n\)-th coordinate map. Definition 2.2 (Smoothness in half spaces) Let \(S\) be an open subset of \(\mathbb H^n\), and \(f: S \to \mathbb R^m\). The function \(f\) is said to be smooth at \(p \in S\) in \(\mathbb H^n\) if it admits an smooth extension in a neighborhood of \(p\) relative to \(\mathbb R^n\). That is, There exists \(g: N \to \mathbb R^m\) defined on an open set \(N \in \mathbb R^m\) that contains \(p\) \(f(x) = g(x)\) for all \(x \in N \cap S\). If so, the differential of \(f\) at \(p\) is defined as the same of that of \(g\). In addition, function \(f\) is said to be smooth in \(\mathbb H^n\) (or simply smooth) if \(f\) is smooth at every point in \(S\). Theorem 2.1 A function \(f: S \to \mathbb R^m\) is smooth in \(\mathbb H^n\) if and only if it admits an extension in a neighborhood of \(S\) that is smooth in \(\mathbb R^n\). Proposition 2.1 The composition of smooth functions are smooth. Chain rule.

3 Manifolds Definition 3.1 (Locally Euclidean) A topologically space \(M\) is locally Euclidean if for all point \(p \in M\), there is a homeomorphism \[ \phi: U \to \mathbb H^n \] defined on a neighborhood of \(p\). The pair \((U, \phi)\) (or simply \(\phi\)) is called a chart of \(M\). Definition 3.2 (Topological Manifold) A topological manifold is a Hausdorff, second countable, locally Euclidean space. Definition 3.3 (Compactible Charts) Two charts of a topological manifold \((U, \phi), (V, \psi)\) are compactible, if \[ \phi \circ \psi^{-1}: \psi(U \cap V) \to \phi(U \cap V), \quad \psi \circ \phi^{-1}: \phi(U \cap V) \to \psi(U \cap V) \] are smooth (in half spaces). Definition 3.4 (Altas) A (smooth) altas on a locally Euclidean space \(M\) is a collection of pairwise compactible charts. Definition 3.5 (Manifold) A smooth manifold is a topological manifold \(M\) together with a maximal atlas. This atlas is also called a differnetial structure of \(M\). Remark. Henceforth refer manifolds as smooth manifolds charts of a manifold as charts in the differential structure of the manifold Proposition 3.1 Any altas is contained in a unique maximal altas. Therefore it is enough to define the differential structure of manifold with an arbitrary atlas. Theorem 3.1 (Smooth invariance of dimension) If \(\phi: U \to \mathbb R^n\), \(\psi: V \to \mathbb R^m\) are two charts of a smooth manifold \(M\), then \(n = m\). Proof. Apply chain rule on the diffeomorphism \(\phi \circ \psi^{-1}\) and its inverse.
4 Tangent Spaces 4.1 Bases for Tangent Spaces 4.2 Tangent Bundle

4 Tangent Spaces Definition 4.1 (Smoothness in manifolds) A function \(f: U \to N\) defined on an open set of a manifold \(M\) is smooth at \(p \in U\) if there are charts \((V, \phi), (W, \psi)\) centered at \(p, f(p)\) resp. such that \[ \psi \circ f \circ \phi^{-1}: \phi(V \cap U \cap f^{-1}(W)) \to \mathbb R^n \] is smooth at \(p\) (in half spaces) A function is smooth if it is smooth everywhere defined. Proposition 4.1 Let \(M, N, R\) be three manifolds, and \(U, V\) open sets of \(M, N\) resp. If functions \[ f: U \to N, \quad g: V \to R \] are defined such that for some point \(p \in U\), \(f(p) \in V\) \(f\) is smooth at \(p\) and \(g\) is smooth at \(f(p)\) Then \(g \circ f\) is smooth at \(p\). Definition 4.2 (Germs) Suppose \(M\) is a manifold, and \(p \in M\). The germs of \(M\) at \(p\) are defined as equivalence classes specified on the set of all functionals defined on a neighborhood of \(p\) such that \(f \sim g\) if they agrees on a (smaller) neighborhood of \(p\). The set of all germs of \(M\) at \(p\) is denoted as \(C^{\infty}_p(M)\). Definition 4.3 In similar fashion, define \(C^\infty_p(M, N)\) as equivalance classes on the set of all smooth functions defined on a neighborhood of \(p \in M\) whose ranges are contained in \(N\) with the equivalence relation that \(f \sim g\) if they agrees on a (smaller) neighborhood of \(p\). Proposition 4.2 The germs \(C^{\infty}_p(M)\) of a manifold at a point is a ring. Definition 4.4 (Tangent vectors) A derivation or tangent vector at a point \(p \in M\) in a manifold is any function \(D: C_p^\infty(M) \to \mathbb R\) such that \[ D(fg) = (Df)g(p) + f(p)(Dg) \] The set of all tangent vectors at \(p\) is called its tangent space, denoted by \(T_pM\). Proposition 4.3 Tangent space at any point in any manifold is a vector space. Definition 4.5 (Differential) Let \(F \in C^\infty_p(M, N)\) be a smooth function defined on an open subset of a manifold \(M\). If \(F\) is smooth at \(p\), then its differential at \(p\) is defined as the map \[ F_*: T_pM \to T_{f(p)}N \] such that \[ F_*(X)(f) = X(f \circ F) \] for all \(f \in C^\infty_{F(p)}(N)\). Proposition 4.4 Differentials are linear transformations between tangent spaces. Theorem 4.1 (Chain rule) If \(F \in C^\infty_p(M, N), G \in C^\infty_f(p)(N, R)\), then \[ (F \circ G)_* = F_* \circ G_* \] 4.1 Bases for Tangent Spaces Definition 4.6 (Partial derivative) If \(M\) is a manifold, \(p \in M\) is a point, and \(\phi: U \to \mathbb R^n\) is a chart centered at \(p\). Write \[ \phi = (x^1, \dots, x^n) \] where \(x^i: U \to \mathbb R^n\). Define \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial x^i} \in T_pM \] with \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}f = \left . \frac{\partial(f \circ \phi^{-1})}{\partial r^i} \right \rvert_{\phi(p)} \] where the right hand side is the usual partial derivative of functions defined in euclidean spaces. Theorem 4.2 Let \(M\) be a manifold, and \(\phi = (x^1, \dots, x^n)\) be a chart at \(p \in M\). The partial derivatives \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial x^1}, \quad \dots, \quad \frac{\partial}{\partial x^n} \] make up a basis for \(T_pM\). Proof. It suffices to prove \(T\mathbb H^n\) has dimension \(n\), or that \(T\mathbb H^n \simeq R^n\). Apply taylor’s expansion with remainder on any \(f \in C^\infty_p(\mathbb R^n)\) with \[ f(x) = f(p) + \sum (x^i - p^i) g_i(x) \] where \(g_i(p) = \left . \frac{\partial f}{\partial x^i} \right \rvert_p\). Proposition 4.5 If \(F \in C^\infty_p(M, N)\), then in local coordinates, \[ F_*\left (\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i} \right) = \sum \frac{\partial F^i}{\partial x^j} \frac{\partial}{\partial y^i} \] where \(F^i = y^i \circ F\). 4.2 Tangent Bundle Definition 4.7 (Tangent bundle) The disjoint union of all tangent spaces of a manifold is called its tangent bundle: \[ TM = \bigsqcup T_pM = \bigcup {p} \times T_pM \] The following defines tangent bundle as a topological space. If \((U, \phi)\) is a chart of \(M\), define \[ TU = \bigcup_{p \in U} T_pM \] The function \(\bar\phi: TU \to \phi(U) \times \mathbb R^n\) defined with \[ \bar \phi(p, v) = (\phi(p), c^1, \dots, c^n) \] where \[ v = \sum c^i \left . \frac{\partial}{\partial x^i} \right \rvert_p \] Transfer the topology from \(U\) to \(TU\), making \(\bar \phi\) a homeomorphism Define the topology on \(TM\) using \[ \mathcal B = \{ B: \text{$B$ is open in $TU$ for some local coordinate $U \subset M$ } \} \] as its basis. The following defines tangent bundle as a smooth manifold. If \(\{(U, \phi)\}\) is an atlas for \(M\), then \(\{TU, \bar \phi\}\) is an atlas for \(TM\).
5 Differential Forms 5.1 Exterior Power of Cotangent Bundle 5.2 Differential Forms

5 Differential Forms Definition 5.1 (Differential) If \(f \in C^\infty_p(M)\), then its differential at \(p\) is defined to be the covector \(df \in T_pM^\vee\) such that \[ (df)_p(X) = X(f) \] Theorem 5.1 At any point \(p \in M\), if \((U, x^1, \dots, x^n)\) is a chart about \(p\), then the differentials \[ dx^1, \quad \dots, \quad dx^n \] comprise a basis for \(T_pM^\vee\) such that \[ df = \sum \frac{\partial f}{\partial x^i} dx^i \] for any \(f \in C_p^\infty(M)\) 5.1 Exterior Power of Cotangent Bundle Definition 5.2 (Cotangent Bundle) The cotangent bundle of a manifold \(M\) is denoted by \(T^*M\), defined in similar fashion of tangent bundle. Definition 5.3 (Alternating tensor) A \(k\)-tensor on a vector space \(V\) is defined as a \(k\)-linear function \[ f: V \times \dots \times V \to \mathbb R \] A \(0\)-tensor is simply defined as a scalar in \(\mathbb R\). A tensor is alternating if \[ f(v_{\sigma(1)}, \dots, v_{\sigma(n)}) = \mathop{\mathrm{sgn}}(\sigma) f(v_1, \dots, v_n) \] where \(\sigma\) is a permutation. Definition 5.4 (Exterior power of vector space) Let \(V\) be a vector space, then the set of all alternating \(k\)-tensors of \(V\) is denoted with \(A_k(V)\) \[ \begin{aligned} A_0(V) &= \mathbb R \\ A_1(V) &= V^\vee \\ \dots \end{aligned} \] Sometimes we also denote \(A_k(V) = \bigwedge^k(V^\vee)\), and refer to the space as the \(k\)-th exterior power of \(V^\vee\). Definition 5.5 (Exterior power of the cotangent bundle) The disjoint union of all \(k\)-th exterior power of all cotangent spaces of a manifold is called the \(k\)-th exterior power of the manifold’s cotangent bundle. \[ \sideset{}{^k}\bigwedge(T^*M) = \bigsqcup_{p \in M} \sideset{}{^k}\bigwedge(T_p^*M) \\ \] Theorem 5.2 At any point \(p \in M\), if \((U, x^1, \dots, x^n)\) is a chart about \(p\), the collection is a basis for the vector space \(\bigwedge^k(T_p^*M)\) \[ dx^I = dx^{i_1} \wedge \dots \wedge dx^{i_k} \] where \(I = \{i_1, \dots, i_k\}\) samples from \(1, \dots, n\) without replacement. That is, if \(\omega \in \bigwedge^k(T_p^*M)\) then \[ \alpha = \sum \alpha \left (\frac{\partial}{\partial x^I}\right ) dx^I \] where \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial x^I} = \left (\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i_1}}, \quad \dots, \quad \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i_n}} \right ) \] Proposition 5.1 The \(k\)-th exterior power of the cotangent bundle can be defined as a smooth manifold in the similar fashion as tangent bundle. 5.2 Differential Forms Definition 5.6 (Differential forms) A differential \(k\)-form \[ \omega: M \to \sideset{}{^k}\bigwedge(T^*M) \] is a section of the vector bundle. Proposition 5.2 If \(\omega\) is a \(k\)-form defined in a neighborhood of \(p\), and written in local coordinates about a point \(p\), \[ \omega = \sum a_I dx^I \] then \(\omega\) is smooth at \(p\) iff all \(a^I\) is smooth at \(p\). Definition 5.7 (Pull back) If \(F: U \subset M \to N\) is a function defined about \(p\), and \(\alpha \in \bigwedge^k(T_p^*N)\), its pull back \(F_*\alpha \in \bigwedge^k(T_p^*M)\) is defined as \[ F^*\alpha(X_1, \dots, X_n) = \alpha(F_*X_1, \dots, F_*X_n) \] If \(F \in C^\infty_p(M, N)\) is a smooth function, \(\omega \in C^\infty(N, \bigwedge^k(T_p^*N))\) is a \(k\)-form, then its pull back is defined pointwise \[ (F^*\omega)_p = F^*(\omega_p) \] then \(F^*\omega_p \in C^\infty(M, \bigwedge^k(T_p^*M))\) (see 5.3). The pull back of a real function \(h\) (\(0\)-form) is the \(0\)-form \[ F^*h = h \circ F \] Definition 5.8 (Codifferential) If \(F \in C^\infty_p(M, N)\), the codifferential is its pull back of a \(1\)-form, or equivalently, the dual of its differential, or equivalently, \[ F^*(\omega)(X) = \omega(F_* X) \] Proposition 5.3 If \(F \in C^\infty_p(M, N)\), then for any \(h \in C^\infty_p(N)\), \[ F^*(dh) = d(F^*h) \] If \(F \in C^\infty_p(M, N)\), \(\omega \in C^\infty_p(M, \bigwedge^r(T^*_M)), \tau \in C^\infty_p(M, \bigwedge^k(T^*_M))\) then their wedge product \(\omega \wedge \tau \in C^\infty_p(M, \bigwedge^{r + k}(T^*_M))\) and \[ F^*(\omega \wedge \tau) = F^*\omega \wedge F^*\tau \] This proves the pull back of a smooth form is smooth.

6 Calculus of variation Definition 6.1 (Calculus of variation) Suppose \(M\) is a manifold, and \(L: TM \to \mathbb R\) is a smooth functional. A curve \(\gamma: \mathbb R \to M\) is said to be a critical point of calculus of variations if in local coordinates \((U, q, \dot q)\), \[ \frac{d}{dt} \left ( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot q} \circ \gamma_* \right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial q} \circ \gamma_* = 0 \] where \[ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial L}{\partial q} &= \left ( \frac{\partial L}{\partial q^1}, \quad \dots, \quad \frac{\partial L}{\partial q^n} \right ) \\ \gamma_* &= (\gamma, \gamma') \end{aligned} \]
7 Orientation 7.1 Orientation by differential forms 7.2 Orientation by atlas

7 Orientation Definition 7.1 (Orientation of vector space) If \(V\) is a vector space of dimension \(n\), the set of all bases of \(V\) is divided in two equivalence classes by the following equivalence relation: \[ \begin{pmatrix} a_1 & \cdots & a_n \end{pmatrix} \sim \begin{pmatrix} b_1 & \cdots & b_n \end{pmatrix} \] if the change of basis matrix \(A\) \[ \begin{pmatrix} a_1 & \cdots & a_n \end{pmatrix} A = \begin{pmatrix} b_1 & \cdots & b_n \end{pmatrix} \] has a positive determinant. Definition 7.2 (Pointwise orientation) Suppose \(M\) is a manifold, a pointwise orientation \(\mu\) assigns each point \(p \in M\) an orientation of its tangent space \(T_pM\). Since orientations are equivalent classes of bases, the pointwise orientation can be represented as a set of vector field \(X_1, \dots, X_n\) on \(M\) \[ \mu = [X_1, \dots, X_n] \] such that \(\mu(p)\) is the orientation specified by the basis \(X_1(p), \dots, X_n(p)\). Definition 7.3 (Continuous orientation) A pointwise orientation \(\mu\) of a manifold is said to be continuous at \(p \in M\) of dimension \(n\) if it can be represented by a collection of continuous vector fields \(X_i\) defined at a neighborhood of \(p\) \[ \mu = [X_1, \dots, X_n] \] where \(X_1, \dots, X_n\) makes up a basis for the tangent space of any point in the neighborhood of \(p\). A manifold is orientable with orientation \(\mu\) if \(\mu\) is continuous everywhere. 7.1 Orientation by differential forms Theorem 7.1 A pointwise orientation \([X_1, \dots, X_n]\) on a manifold \(M\) is continuous at \(p\) if and only if everywhere there is a local coordinate \((U, x^1, \dots, x^n)\) such that \[ dx^1 \wedge \dots \wedge dx^n (X_1, \dots, X_n) > 0 \] on \(U\). Theorem 7.2 A manifold \(M\) of dimension \(n\) is orientable if and only if there exists a nowhere vanishing smooth \(n\)-form. Proof. Apply partition of unity on the previous theorem. 7.2 Orientation by atlas Definition 7.4 (Oriented altas) An atlas \(\{(\phi)\}\) is oriented if the Jacobian of the change of coordinates \[ \psi \circ \phi^{-1} \] is everywhere positive. Theorem 7.3 An atlas \(\{(x^1, \dots, x^n)\}\) is oriented if and only if there exists a orientation \(n\)-form \(\omega\) such that \[ \omega\left ( \frac{\partial}{\partial x^1}, \dots, \frac{\partial}{\partial x^n} \right ) > 0 \] written in local coordinates.

8 Boundary Definition 8.1 (Boundary of half space) Recall the half space is defined as \[ \mathbb H^n = \{ (x^1, \dots, x^n) : x^n \ge 0 \} \] Its boundary is defined as the set \[ \mathbb \partial H^n = \{ (x^1, \dots, x^n) : x^n = 0 \} \] Its interior is the remainder of the set \[ \mathbb (H^n)^{\circ} = \{ (x^1, \dots, x^n) : x^n > 0 \} \] Theorem 8.1 Let \(U, V\) be open sets of \(\mathbb H^n\). If \(f: U \to V\) is a smooth function in \(\mathbb H^n\), then \(f\) maps interior point of \(\mathbb H^n\) to interior point of \(\mathbb H^n\), and boundary points to boundary points. ::: {.definition name=“Boundary of manifolds”} If \(M\) is a manifold of dimension \(n\), its boundary \(\partial M\) is defined as the set of all points that is mapped to \(\partial \mathbb H^n\) by some local chart of \(\mathbb M\). If \(\{(U, \phi) \}\) is an atlas of \(M\), then \(\{ (U \cap \partial M, \phi |_{U \cap \partial M}) \}\) can serve as an atlas of \(\partial M\), where \[ \phi|_{U \cap \partial M}: (U \cap \partial M) \to \partial \mathbb H^n = \mathbb R^{n - 1} \] Hence \(\partial M\) has dimension \(n - 1\). The above atlas maps neighborhoods of \(\partial M\) to \(\mathbb R^{n-1}\) not \(\mathbb H^{n-1}\), violating our definition. This is fixed by a diffeomorphism between \(\mathbb R^{n-1}\) and any open ball \(B\) of \(\mathbb R^{n-1}\) that resides in \(\mathbb H^{n-1}\). 8.1 Interior Multiplication Definition 8.2 (Interior multiplication) If \(\beta\) is a \(k\)-covector on a vector space \(V\), the interior multiplication, or contraction of \(\beta\) with a vector \(v \in V\) is the \((k - 1)\)-covector \[ \iota_v \beta (v_2, \dots, v_k) = \beta(v, v_2, \dots, v_k) \] Define \(\iota_v(\beta) = 0\) for any \(0\)-covector \(\beta\). Proposition 8.1 For covectors \(\alpha^1, \dots, \alpha^k\) on a vector space \(V\), and \(v \in V\) \[ \iota_v(\alpha^1 \wedge \dots \wedge \alpha^k) = \sum^k_{i=1} (-1)^{i-1} \alpha^i(v) \alpha^1 \wedge \dots \wedge \hat {\alpha^i} \wedge \dots \wedge \alpha^k \] 8.2 Boundary Orientation Proposition 8.2 The inclusion map \(i: \partial M \to M\) is smooth, its differential is an injection from tangent spaces of \(\partial M\) to those of \(M\). However, such injection is not a surjection, and in particular \(\partial/\partial x_n\) is not in the range for any local chart \((x^1, \dots, x^n)\) of \(M\). At a point \(p \in \partial M\), identify the tangent space \(T_p(\partial M)\) as a subspace of \(T_pM\) by the above proposition. Definition 8.3 (Outward pointing vector) A vector \(X\) of \(T_pM \setminus T_p \partial M\) at \(p \in \partial M\) is said to be inward pointing if there exists curve \(c: (-1, 1) \to M\) such that \(c(0, 1) \subset M^\circ\) \(c(0) = p\) \(c'(0) = X\) The vector \(X\) is outward pointing if \(-X\) is inward pointing. Definition 8.4 (Smooth outward pointing vector field) A vector field along \(\partial M\) assigns each \(p \in \partial M\) a vector \(X_p \in T_pM\). Such vector field is said to be smooth at \(p\) if written in local coordinates of \(M\), \[ X = \sum a_i \frac{\partial}{\partial x^i} \] \(a_i\) is smooth at \(p\) in \(\partial M\), i.e., \(a_i \in C^\infty_p(\partial M)\). Theorem 8.2 There exists a smooth outward pointing vector field along \(\partial M\) for any smooth manifold \(M\). Theorem 8.3 If \(\omega\) is an orientation form of \(M\), and \(X\) is a smooth outward pointing vector field along \(\partial M\), then \(\iota_X\omega\) is an orientation form of \(\partial M\).

9 Integration Definition 9.1 (Integration on Euclidean spaces) If \(A \subset \mathbb R^n\), and a smooth \(n\)-form \(\omega\) is defined on a neighborhood of \(A\), then with stardard coordinates, \(\omega = f dx^1 \wedge \dots \wedge dx^n\), and its integration on \(A\) is given by \[ \int_A \omega = \int_A f(x) dx^1 \cdots dx^n \] Definition 9.2 (Integration on Manifolds) If \((U, \phi)\) is a chart of a manifold \(M\), and \(\omega\) is an \(n\)-form with compact support in \(U\), then the integral of \(\omega\) on \(U\) is defined as \[ \int_U \omega = \int_{\phi(U)} \left ((\phi)^{-1} \right)^* \omega \] If \(\{(U, \phi)\}\) is an oriented atlas of \(M\), choose a partition of unity \(\{ \rho \}\) subordinate to the atlas. If \(\omega\) is an \(n\)-form defined on \(M\) with compact support, then \[ \omega = \sum \rho \omega \] is a finite sum, and the integral of \(\omega\) over \(M\) with respect to the current orientation is defined as \[ \int_M \omega = \sum \int_U \rho\omega \] Theorem 9.1 (Stokes) If \(\omega\) is an \((n-1)\)-form on a manifold \(M\), then \[ \int_M d\omega = \int_{\partial M} i^*\omega \] where \(i: \partial M \to M\) is the natural inclusion.
